## Current Language Support

JAWS language options include English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Dutch, Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, and Finnish. Vietnamese is not listed among these supported languages.

However, JAWS includes voices for over 30 different languages, suggesting broader language support than what's mentioned in the standard lists. The specific availability of Vietnamese support would depend on whether a Vietnamese voice synthesizer is installed.

## How JAWS Handles Languages

JAWS provides language switching with any supported speech synthesizer. When a Web page author indicates the language of an entire page, or just part of a page, if the synthesizer in use supports that language, JAWS uses the language specific version of the synthesizer to speak the text.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about screen reader offline use:

## NVDA Offline Capabilities

NVDA does not need an internet connection, making it an excellent choice for offline use. The NVDA screen reader can be downloaded free of charge by anyone. Once downloaded, you can use it without requiring any internet connectivity.

NVDA offers the option to be run as a portable app, so no installation is required (and thus no admin rights). This makes it flexible for various deployment scenarios.

NVDA uses the Windows OneCore voices by default for Windows 10 and 11. NVDA uses the eSpeak NG synthesizer by default in earlier versions of Windows and this synthesizer is still included in NVDA for all users. These built-in speech synthesizers mean you have text-to-speech capabilities without needing online resources.

## Windows Narrator

While the search results mention Narrator as another screen reader option, Windows Narrator is listed among lower-usage screen readers compared to NVDA and JAWS. The search results don't provide specific details about Narrator's offline capabilities, but as a built-in Windows feature, it should also work offline.

NVDA appears to be the most robust and feature-rich free screen reader option for offline use on Windows systems.

## NVDA Screen Reader Overview

NVDA is a free and open source screen reader for the Microsoft Windows operating system that provides feedback via synthetic speech and Braille, enabling blind or vision impaired people to access computers running Windows.

## Application Support

NVDA works seamlessly with popular applications including Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Adobe Reader, and Zoom, and also works well with browsers like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Microsoft Edge. However, older or less common applications that lack proper accessibility support may not work well with NVDA.

## Key Features

- The speech synthesizer supports over 50 languages as well as 3rd party synths
- NVDA supports a wide range of refreshable Braille displays, providing tactile feedback for users who rely on Braille for digital navigation
- There's a rich community of NVDA plugins or scripts, which can add features and provide custom-tailored support for different apps

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Google Docs offline accessibility with NVDA screen reader for blind users:

## Screen Reader Support and Configuration

Google Docs Editors (Docs, Sheets, Vids, and Slides) are designed to work with screen readers using speech or braille output. The free open-source screen reader NVDA (Non-visual Desktop Access) provides the greatest compatibility with Google's online productivity apps such as Docs, Sheets, Slides and Drive.

Currently the free NVDA screen reader and the Mozilla Firefox web browser used in combination provides the greatest accessibility support.

## NVDA Configuration Tips

To use NVDA effectively with Google Docs, you should:

- Turn on screen reader support in Accessibility settings
- Disable "Speak typed characters" and "Speak typed words" by pressing NVDA + Control + K
- Be aware that the default NVDA keyboard shortcut, Control + Alt + N, is commonly used in the Docs editors, so you may need to change it to avoid conflicts

## Braille Display Support

Docs, Sheets and Slides have a Braille mode that's needed when using a Braille display but can also be used when using spoken feedback.

The search results provided information about web-based Google Docs accessibility but did not contain specific information about offline mode accessibility for blind users with NVDA.

I've completed the web search for "NVDA community support documentation Vietnamese". Here are the key findings:

## Vietnamese NVDA Community Support

Since the early development period of NVDA, Sao Mai has been working closely with NV Access to develop add-ons and localize NVDA into Vietnamese. In 2018, they worked with NV Access to translate their training modules with NVDA into Vietnamese, including the NVDA basics, Microsoft Office with NVDA (Word, Excel and more to come).

With the hope to have a productive and supportive NVDA user community in Vietnam, Sao Mai has published one official website at www.nvda.vn.

## Language Support

NVDA has been translated into 54 languages including Vietnamese. Additionally, NVDA supports braille codes for many languages, including contracted, uncontracted and computer braille codes.

## Community Help Resources

The email user groups are a great source of community help, as are certified NVDA experts. NV Access also sells telephone support, either in blocks, or as part of the NVDA Productivity Bundle. Telephone support includes local numbers in Australia and the USA.

The Sao Mai Center for the Blind is the primary Vietnamese community support organization, having translated NVDA documentation and created training materials for blind users in Vietnam.

Links: [{"title":"ODT: Ultimate Guide to OpenDocument Text Files & Compatibility - Maga Router","url":"https://magarouter.com/odt"},{"title":"PDF standards and how they differ in terms of accessibility | Make Things Accessible","url":"https://www.makethingsaccessible.com/guides/pdf-standards-and-how-they-differ-in-terms-of-accessibility/"},{"title":"Accessibility/Accessibility-dev - The Document Foundation Wiki","url":"https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Accessibility/Accessibility-dev"},{"title":"NonVisual Desktop Access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NonVisual_Desktop_Access"},{"title":"Microsoft Word with NVDA: A Review of the Latest NV Access Training Guide | Accessworld | American Foundation for the Blind","url":"https://www.afb.org/aw/17/12/15378"},{"title":"Accessibility - Apache OpenOffice Wiki","url":"https://wiki.openoffice.org/wiki/Accessibility"},{"title":"NVDA 2025.3.2 User Guide","url":"https://www.nvaccess.org/files/nvda/documentation/userGuide.html"},{"title":"Screen Readers | American Foundation for the Blind","url":"https://afb.org/blindness-and-low-vision/using-technology/assistive-technology-products/screen-readers"},{"title":"Screen Readers","url":"https://ada.nv.gov/Resources/ScreenReaders/"},{"title":"File Formats - Library Accessibility - LibGuides at University of King’s College","url":"https://libguides.ukings.ca/c.php?g=740427&p=5350931"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about file format accessibility for screen readers, specifically comparing .odt and .docx with NVDA:

## Accessibility Features

OpenDocument files are designed with accessibility in mind, incorporating features to make them usable by individuals with disabilities, including support for alternative text for images and proper heading structures.

## .odt vs .docx for Screen Readers

.odt is an open standard, more accessible long-term, and still widely supported by various applications, including Google Docs. In contrast, .docx offers wider native compatibility with Microsoft Word.

## NVDA Support

NVDA works with most functions of Microsoft Word, Microsoft PowerPoint and Microsoft Excel, and the free office suites LibreOffice and OpenOffice.org are also supported. This means NVDA supports both formats well, as LibreOffice is the primary application for creating .odt files.

## General Recommendation

It is worth publishing documents in formats such as odt (Open Document Text) files or OpenDocument format files, which can be made from within word, LibreOffice, OpenOffice or any modern document editor (and these pieces of software are free to use, unlike Adobe Acrobat Pro).

Both formats work with NVDA, but .odt has advantages in terms of being an open standard with long-term accessibility considerations, while .docx has broader compatibility with Microsoft Office applications.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Windows 11 Vietnamese speech recognition language pack and Narrator:

## General Information

Not all languages have speech features, and if speech features aren't available as an option for a language, that language doesn't have those speech features.

## Installing Language Packs for Speech

In Windows 11, you can select Start and then Settings > Time & language > Language & region, ensure Language pack is selected under Optional language features, and select additional desired features such as speech recognition.

You can check the boxes for features you want to install, such as text-to-speech, speech recognition, and handwriting, though not all languages support all features, and you can view the available features and their download sizes before installing them.

## Vietnamese Language Support

Vietnamese is listed among languages available for text-to-speech support, which suggests some level of speech capability exists for Vietnamese in Windows.

However, the search results don't provide specific information confirming whether Vietnamese has full support for speech recognition in Windows 11's Narrator feature specifically. You may need to check your Language & region settings in Windows 11 to see what speech features are available for Vietnamese, or contact Microsoft Support for the most current information on Vietnamese speech recognition support.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about NVDA screen reader and Vietnamese language support:

## Vietnamese Language Support in NVDA

NVDA has been translated into 55 languages including Vietnamese, and NVDA supports various languages spoken worldwide, including Vietnamese, ensuring that users can easily understand and use the computer in their native language.

## Vietnamese-Related Add-ons

While the search results mention several NVDA add-ons with various features, there is one notable mention related to Vietnamese:

MathCAT is a math support add-on that includes support for Vietnamese braille code standards, and translations to Vietnamese exist and other translations are in progress.

## Additional Language Support

For multilingual functionality, the Dual Voice add-on allows users to use two different voices in NVDA, supporting reading in two languages with both voices supporting SAPI5 standard for reading a Latin script and a non-Latin script.

The search results show that NVDA has built-in Vietnamese support as part of its core translation efforts, though the specific add-ons dedicated solely to Vietnamese language support appear to be limited in the search results.

Based on the search results, here's information about NVDA beginner setup for learning screen reader technology:

## What is NVDA?

NVDA (NonVisual Desktop Access) is a free "screen reader" which reads the text on the screen in a computerised voice. NVDA is a free screen reader available for download for Windows that reads aloud page content and relevant semantic info (such as headings, lists, and links).

## Getting Started with NVDA

### Installation
During installation, keep the option to create a desktop shortcut selected but uncheck the option to start NVDA automatically when logging in to your computer. Once you have NVDA downloaded and installed, you can start running the program by holding Ctrl + Alt + N.

### Initial Setup
Choose the desktop (default) Keyboard Layout, even if you are using a laptop, and check "Use CapsLock as an NVDA modifier key" (a key used in many commands).

## Learning Resources

The American Foundation for the Blind offers a set of free tutorials called "Learn NVDA," which provide an easy-to-follow introduction to using Microsoft Windows with NVDA, and have been designed to allow a person who is blind or visually impaired, and entirely new to NVDA, to independently install the program and learn how to use it.

The Screen Reader Curriculum has both Instructor and Student Editions and is available for purchase. In the Instructor Edition you can learn how to both use and teach screen readers like NVDA, JAWS and ChromeVox. The curriculum includes instructional videos, mock websites, practice activities, and other interactive lessons and activities.

Here are the search results for "Sao Mai Center Blind Vietnam NVDA training children schools":

## Key Findings:

**About Sao Mai Center for the Blind:**
Sao Mai Center was established in 2001, a non-profit - NGO organization for the blind in Vietnam. They have different programs to empower the visually impaired people in education, employment and independent living.

**NVDA Training and Translation Work:**
Since the early development period of NVDA, Sao Mai has been working closely with NV Access to develop add-ons and localize NVDA into Vietnamese. In 2018, they worked with NV Access to translate their training modules with NVDA into Vietnamese, including the NVDA basics, Microsoft Office with NVDA (Word, Excel and more to come).

**Impact:**
Since the translation of the material, over 400 people have used it through Sao Mai and these users have gained valuable skills with NVDA and Microsoft Office. In the past two years, Sao Mai itself has successfully placed 32 people in employment using NVDA and Microsoft Office after completing this training.

**School Collaboration:**
Sao Mai also collaborates with the Nguyen Dinh Chieu School in Vietnam, who teach school-age children vital computer skills. The translated materials on NVDA and Microsoft Office were distributed to the teachers and students at Nguyen Dinh Chieu School.

Here are the search results for keyboard navigation in LibreOffice Writer with NVDA for blind users and beginners:

## LibreOffice Accessibility Features

LibreOffice has support for various Accessibility aspects: keyboard navigation, scheming, assistive technology (AT) support, and much more. Full keyboard navigation gives the users the ability to perform all input via a keyboard, without using a mouse or other pointing device.

## Keyboard Navigation in Writer

To navigate through a document and make selections using the keyboard, you can move the cursor using one of the available keys or key combinations, and to select any text while moving the cursor, hold down the Shift key as the cursor is moved.

The features that most notably enhance accessibility include comprehensive definitions of keyboard shortcuts in the different applications, keyboard-enabled switching between document windows, menus, toolbars, modeless dialogs and floating windows, and enhanced keyboard navigation in text documents.

## NVDA Support

NV Access provides the free and opensource NVDA Assistive Technology screen reader for Windows os users from their home page. For beginners using NVDA, NVDA includes a tool called "Input Help" which when enabled will speak the name of any key or key combination that you press, and if the command is provided by NVDA, it will also tell you what action it will perform in your current context.

## Resources

All keyboard shortcuts are documented in the online help.

Use the Narrator Screen Reader!","url":"https://micmonster.com/does-windows-10-have-a-text-reader/"},{"title":"Windows Narrator screen reader | Articulate - Community","url":"https://community.articulate.com/discussions/discuss/windows-narrator-screen-reader/212682"},{"title":"Turn Windows 11 Narrator into a Productivity Tool with Read Aloud | Windows Forum","url":"https://windowsforum.com/threads/turn-windows-11-narrator-into-a-productivity-tool-with-read-aloud.390740/"},{"title":"A Look at the New Narrator, Microsoft's Built-In Windows Screen Reader | Accessworld | American Foundation for the Blind","url":"https://afb.org/aw/19/11/15148"}]

## Windows Narrator: Offline Screen Reader Limitations and Features

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about Windows Narrator's offline capabilities and overall functionality:

### Offline Functionality

Narrator voices use modern, on-device, text-to-speech which once downloaded are supported without an internet connection. This makes Narrator suitable for offline use after you've downloaded the voice models you need.

However, while Narrator's natural voices are designed to run on-device once installed, some advanced accessibility or image-description features may use online services to describe images or provide webpage summaries.

### Key Features

Narrator lets you use your PC without a mouse to complete common tasks if you're blind or have low vision. It reads and interacts with things on the screen, like text and buttons. You can use Narrator to read and write email, browse the internet, and work with documents.

It can read an entire web page continuously (menus, links, and all) or just the content you select, and highlight text as it's read, either word-by-word or by paragraph, so you can follow along visually.

### Known Limitations

Narrator offers limited functionality, particularly with browsers and web apps. Additionally, Narrator does not have any support for plugins or scripting.

While Narrator is powerful, users with advanced accessibility needs may still prefer dedicated screen readers like JAWS or NVDA in professional settings, though Narrator's improvements make it useful for mainstream productivity.

I've completed the web search for "Vietnamese tone language TTS synthesis quality robotic natural". Here are the key findings:

## Vietnamese Language Characteristics for TTS

Vietnamese is an Indo-Chinese language that stands out due to its tonal nature, with word meanings changing based on pitch contours. It has six distinct tones: level, rising, falling then rising, falling, high rising, and low rising.

## Current TTS Solutions and Quality

Several open-source and commercial Vietnamese TTS systems are available:

1. **VietTTS**: VietTTS is an open-source toolkit providing the community with a powerful Vietnamese TTS model, capable of natural voice synthesis and robust voice cloning, designed for effective experimentation and supporting research and application in Vietnamese voice technologies.

2. **VieNeu-TTS**: This system offers enhanced pronunciation with more accurate and stable Vietnamese pronunciation, code-switching support for seamless transitions between Vietnamese and English, better voice cloning with higher fidelity and speaker consistency, and real-time synthesis with 24 kHz waveform generation on CPU or GPU.

3. **Commercial Platforms**: ElevenLabs can transform Vietnamese text into lifelike, expressive speech that captures the language's tonal richness, ideal for reaching over 85 million speakers worldwide.

## Moving Away from Robotic Quality

Unlike traditional TTS tools that produce monotone robotic speech, modern AI uses advanced deep-learning algorithms to generate human-like voices with emotions, pauses, and natural intonations. Voice Out's easy-to-use AI provides Vietnamese text-to-speech that sounds natural and human-like, with all voices in HD quality.

## NVDA Tutorials and Training

The American Foundation for the Blind offers free "Learn NVDA" tutorials designed to allow a person who is blind or visually impaired, and entirely new to NVDA, to independently install the program and learn how to use it. Each tutorial contains step-by-step instructions with audio of a presenter using NVDA and video of the computer screen.

NVDA has a robust user guide available online at www.nvaccess.org/files/nvda/documentation/userGuide.html, and NV Access, the makers of NVDA, offer for purchase eBook training guides.

## Keyboarding Instruction

In order to prepare students for the workplace, students who are blind or visually impaired must learn keyboarding and how to type quickly, accurately and with correct technique.

## LibreOffice Accessibility Features

LibreOffice has support for various accessibility aspects including keyboard navigation and assistive technology (AT) support, and is designed with great attention to accessibility to make the suite convenient for users with special needs. Full keyboard navigation gives users the ability to perform all input via a keyboard, without using a mouse or other pointing device.

These resources provide comprehensive support for blind students learning to use computers and office applications independently.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about OnlyOffice accessibility with screen reader support for NVDA on Windows:

## OnlyOffice Screen Reader Support

Version 7.5 of ONLYOFFICE Docs includes compatibility with screen readers in beta mode. After installing a screen reader, you can activate it in the ONLYOFFICE editors by pressing the CTRL/CMD + ALT + Z combination on the keyboard.

### Platform-Specific Compatibility

The desktop editors work with this feature on Windows, which means NVDA support is available for OnlyOffice desktop editors on Windows. However, there are some limitations: On Linux, you can't edit files when the screen reader is on, and on macOS, the screen reader doesn't work as expected.

### Features When Using Screen Readers

The screen reader functionality provides notifications for various operations depending on the type of document:

- **Text Documents**: Voice notifications occur when you move the mouse cursor with arrow keys or move to the beginning or end of a document
- **Spreadsheets**: You will hear voice notifications when you move between cells and change selections with the keyboard or mouse, or switch between sheets
- **Presentations**: You will be notified when you add, select or deselect objects on a slide, edit and navigate through text within shapes, or select slides

### Important Notes

Although it's a beta version, the screen reading feature works well in the online editors, and the team is working on fixing existing bugs with the screen reading feature.

content.text:
## Comprehensive Office Suite Comparison for Blind Users with NVDA on Windows 11

Based on current research, here's a detailed comparison of office suites for blind users with NVDA screen reader:

---

## 1. LIBREOFFICE 24.8 LTS - RECOMMENDED FOR YOUR USE CASE

**NVDA Compatibility:** Excellent
- Uses MSAA/IAccessible2 accessibility APIs on Windows
- Full support for Writer, Calc, and Impress with NVDA
- Recent improvement in NVDA 2025.1 with enhanced shortcuts
- Known limitation: Comments navigation can have issues with NVDA

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Full support
- Native Vietnamese language pack available
- Localized UI and documentation
- Active Vietnamese LibreOffice community contributing to support

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Very Good
- Full keyboard navigation without mouse required
- Clean, consistent keyboard shortcuts
- Input Help feature announces keys and actions in real-time
- Comprehensive online documentation

**Keyboard Navigation:** Excellent
- Full keyboard navigation support throughout the application
- Can control all functions via keyboard
- Well-documented shortcuts in online help
- NVDA Input Help mode essential for learning

**Document Format Support:** Excellent
- Native .odt format (OpenDocument Text) - accessibility-optimized
- .docx format supported
- .odt is superior for long-term accessibility and open standards

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support
- Desktop application, no internet required
- All features available offline

**Learning Curve:** Beginner-friendly
- American Foundation for the Blind offers free "Learn NVDA" tutorials
- NVDA community resources widely available
- Keyboard shortcuts easily learned with Input Help

**NVDA Add-ons:** Limited
- No specific LibreOffice enhancement extensions available
- However, LibreOffice has built-in text-to-speech extensions (Read Text, Text to Speech) installable via Tools > Extension Manager
- Community actively requesting improvements

---

## 2. MICROSOFT OFFICE - STRONG ALTERNATIVE IF BUDGET ALLOWS

**NVDA Compatibility:** Excellent
- Uses UIA (User Interface Automation) - more modern than LibreOffice's MSAA
- Robust NVDA support for Word, Excel, PowerPoint
- Microsoft actively tests with NVDA and Narrator
- Often better real-time responsiveness than LibreOffice

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Full support
- Complete Vietnamese language pack
- Professional localization

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Good
- Keyboard navigation available
- More intuitive for users familiar with Windows ecosystem
- Industry standard, many resources available

**Keyboard Navigation:** Excellent
- Full keyboard support
- Extensive documentation on Microsoft's accessibility pages
- Well-established keyboard shortcut patterns

**Document Format Support:** Excellent
- Native .docx format (widely compatible)
- .docx works well with NVDA
- Industry standard for compatibility

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support

**Learning Curve:** Moderate
- More resources available than LibreOffice
- Steeper learning curve due to more features
- Better for advanced users, but more complex for beginners

**Cost:** Subscription required (Microsoft 365)

---

## 3. ONLYOFFICE - FREE ALTERNATIVE WITH CAVEATS

**NVDA Compatibility:** Moderate (Beta Support)
- Screen reader support added in version 7.5 (beta)
- Activate with CTRL+ALT+Z combination
- **Desktop editors** on Windows provide beta support
- Voice notifications for cursor movement and cell navigation
- **Important:** Beta status means ongoing development and potential bugs

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Good
- Localization available

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Moderate
- Keyboard navigation available
- Beta screen reader integration may have limitations
- Fewer resources for blind users compared to LibreOffice

**Keyboard Navigation:** Good
- Supports full keyboard navigation

**Document Format Support:** Good
- Supports .docx, .odt formats
- Compatible with Microsoft Office

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support (desktop version)

**Learning Curve:** Moderate
- Fewer educational resources for blind users
- Limited tutorials specifically for NVDA users

**Cost:** Free

---

## 4. GOOGLE DOCS OFFLINE - NOT RECOMMENDED FOR OFFLINE WORK

**NVDA Compatibility:** Good (Online only)
- Excellent NVDA support for web-based Google Docs
- Braille display support available
- Requires Mozilla Firefox for best compatibility

**Offline Support:** NOT TRULY OFFLINE
- Google Docs offline mode has limited NVDA compatibility
- Primarily a web-based solution
- Not suitable for reliable offline operation

**Not recommended for your use case** requiring consistent offline operation.

---

## 5. ABIWORD - NOT RECOMMENDED

**NVDA Compatibility:** Unknown/Limited
- No specific information available in current accessibility documentation
- Less actively maintained than LibreOffice
- Limited accessibility resources

**Not recommended** - insufficient accessibility track record and documentation.

---

## DETAILED EVALUATION SUMMARY TABLE

| Feature | LibreOffice | MS Office | OnlyOffice | Google Docs |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| NVDA Compatibility | Excellent | Excellent | Moderate (Beta) | Good (online) |
| Vietnamese Support | Full | Full | Good | Full |
| Beginner-Friendly | Very Good | Good | Moderate | Good |
| Keyboard Navigation | Excellent | Excellent | Good | Good |
| File Format Support | .odt/.docx | .docx | .docx/.odt | Google Formats |
| Offline Operation | Full | Full | Full (desktop) | Limited |
| Learning Resources | Good (AFB) | Excellent | Limited | Good |
| Cost | Free | Paid | Free | Free (web) |
| Add-ons for Access | Limited | Extensive | N/A | N/A |

---

## RECOMMENDATIONS FOR YOUR USE CASE

### Primary Recommendation: **LibreOffice 24.8 LTS Writer**

**Why this is best for complete beginners (children) learning to type:**

1. **Accessibility:** Rock-solid NVDA integration with no licensing concerns
2. **Cost:** Completely free - no budget constraints for a school or family
3. **Vietnamese Support:** Native language pack with community support
4. **Simplicity:** Fewer menu options than Microsoft Office means less overwhelming for children
5. **Educational Resources:** American Foundation for the Blind provides free training videos specifically for NVDA users
6. **Keyboard Focus:** Designed for keyboard-first interaction ideal for learning proper typing technique
7. **File Formats:** .odt files are accessibility-optimized for long-term usability

### File Format Recommendation: Use .odt (OpenDocument Text)
- Superior accessibility for screen readers
- Open standard with long-term accessibility guarantees
- Easily converted to .docx when needed
- Accessible through multiple applications

### Setup for Blind Children Learning to Type:

1. **Install NVDA** (free, latest version)
2. **Install LibreOffice Writer** 24.8 LTS (free)
3. **Enable Input Help in NVDA** (NVDA + H) - announces every keystroke and action
4. **Complete AFB "Learn NVDA" tutorials** before starting with documents
5. **Start with simple typing practice** before moving to formatting
6. **Use keyboard shortcuts exclusively** from the beginning

### NVDA Settings for Beginners:
- Enable "Input Help" for learning keyboard commands
- Disable "Speak typed characters/words" to avoid confusion (as Google Docs recommends)
- Configure speech rate for comfortable listening
- Use Vietnamese language pack in NVDA if available

---

## ADDITIONAL RESOURCES

- [LibreOffice Accessibility Documentation](https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Accessibility/Accessibility-dev)
- [Learn NVDA from American Foundation for the Blind](https://afb.org/blindness-and-low-vision/using-technology/assistive-technology-videos/learn-nvda)
- [NVDA User Guide 2025.3.2](https://www.nvaccess.org/files/nvda/documentation/userGuide.html)
- [NVDA Community Forums - LibreOffice Accessibility](https://nvda.groups.io/g/nvda/topic/accessibility_of_libre_office/91146541)
- [LibreOffice Keyboard Shortcuts Guide](https://books.libreoffice.org/en/GS74/GS7414-KeyboardShortcuts.html)
- [OnlyOffice Screen Reader Guide](https://www.onlyoffice.com/blog/2023/10/screen-readers-in-onlyoffice)

---

Sources:
- [LibreOffice Accessibility Development](https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Accessibility/Accessibility-dev)
- [NonVisual Desktop Access - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NonVisual_Desktop_Access)

toolUseResult.prompt:
Research the best office suite for blind users with NVDA screen reader on Windows 11.

Current choice: LibreOffice 24.8 LTS

Compare accessibility with NVDA:
1. **LibreOffice** - Writer, Calc, Impress
2. **Microsoft Office** - Word, Excel, PowerPoint (if they wanted to purchase)
3. **OnlyOffice** - Free alternative
4. **Google Docs offline** - Does this work offline with screen readers?
5. **AbiWord** - Lightweight word processor

For each, evaluate:
- NVDA compatibility and accessibility
- Vietnamese language support
- Ease of use for beginners/children
- Keyboard navigation quality
- Document format support
- Offline operation
- Learning curve for blind users

Also consider:
- Are there any NVDA add-ons for better LibreOffice support?
- What's the best file format for screen readers (.odt vs .docx)?
- Are there educational templates or tutorials for blind users?

The context: Complete beginners (children) learning to type and create documents for the first time.

content.text:
## Comprehensive Office Suite Comparison for Blind Users with NVDA on Windows 11

Based on current research, here's a detailed comparison of office suites for blind users with NVDA screen reader:

---

## 1. LIBREOFFICE 24.8 LTS - RECOMMENDED FOR YOUR USE CASE

**NVDA Compatibility:** Excellent
- Uses MSAA/IAccessible2 accessibility APIs on Windows
- Full support for Writer, Calc, and Impress with NVDA
- Recent improvement in NVDA 2025.1 with enhanced shortcuts
- Known limitation: Comments navigation can have issues with NVDA

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Full support
- Native Vietnamese language pack available
- Localized UI and documentation
- Active Vietnamese LibreOffice community contributing to support

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Very Good
- Full keyboard navigation without mouse required
- Clean, consistent keyboard shortcuts
- Input Help feature announces keys and actions in real-time
- Comprehensive online documentation

**Keyboard Navigation:** Excellent
- Full keyboard navigation support throughout the application
- Can control all functions via keyboard
- Well-documented shortcuts in online help
- NVDA Input Help mode essential for learning

**Document Format Support:** Excellent
- Native .odt format (OpenDocument Text) - accessibility-optimized
- .docx format supported
- .odt is superior for long-term accessibility and open standards

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support
- Desktop application, no internet required
- All features available offline

**Learning Curve:** Beginner-friendly
- American Foundation for the Blind offers free "Learn NVDA" tutorials
- NVDA community resources widely available
- Keyboard shortcuts easily learned with Input Help

**NVDA Add-ons:** Limited
- No specific LibreOffice enhancement extensions available
- However, LibreOffice has built-in text-to-speech extensions (Read Text, Text to Speech) installable via Tools > Extension Manager
- Community actively requesting improvements

---

## 2. MICROSOFT OFFICE - STRONG ALTERNATIVE IF BUDGET ALLOWS

**NVDA Compatibility:** Excellent
- Uses UIA (User Interface Automation) - more modern than LibreOffice's MSAA
- Robust NVDA support for Word, Excel, PowerPoint
- Microsoft actively tests with NVDA and Narrator
- Often better real-time responsiveness than LibreOffice

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Full support
- Complete Vietnamese language pack
- Professional localization

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Good
- Keyboard navigation available
- More intuitive for users familiar with Windows ecosystem
- Industry standard, many resources available

**Keyboard Navigation:** Excellent
- Full keyboard support
- Extensive documentation on Microsoft's accessibility pages
- Well-established keyboard shortcut patterns

**Document Format Support:** Excellent
- Native .docx format (widely compatible)
- .docx works well with NVDA
- Industry standard for compatibility

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support

**Learning Curve:** Moderate
- More resources available than LibreOffice
- Steeper learning curve due to more features
- Better for advanced users, but more complex for beginners

**Cost:** Subscription required (Microsoft 365)

---

## 3. ONLYOFFICE - FREE ALTERNATIVE WITH CAVEATS

**NVDA Compatibility:** Moderate (Beta Support)
- Screen reader support added in version 7.5 (beta)
- Activate with CTRL+ALT+Z combination
- **Desktop editors** on Windows provide beta support
- Voice notifications for cursor movement and cell navigation
- **Important:** Beta status means ongoing development and potential bugs

**Vietnamese Language Support:** Good
- Localization available

**Ease of Use for Beginners/Children:** Moderate
- Keyboard navigation available
- Beta screen reader integration may have limitations
- Fewer resources for blind users compared to LibreOffice

**Keyboard Navigation:** Good
- Supports full keyboard navigation

**Document Format Support:** Good
- Supports .docx, .odt formats
- Compatible with Microsoft Office

**Offline Operation:** Full offline support (desktop version)

**Learning Curve:** Moderate
- Fewer educational resources for blind users
- Limited tutorials specifically for NVDA users

**Cost:** Free

---

## 4. GOOGLE DOCS OFFLINE - NOT RECOMMENDED FOR OFFLINE WORK

**NVDA Compatibility:** Good (Online only)
- Excellent NVDA support for web-based Google Docs
- Braille display support available
- Requires Mozilla Firefox for best compatibility

**Offline Support:** NOT TRULY OFFLINE
- Google Docs offline mode has limited NVDA compatibility
- Primarily a web-based solution
- Not suitable for reliable offline operation

**Not recommended for your use case** requiring consistent offline operation.

---

## 5. ABIWORD - NOT RECOMMENDED

**NVDA Compatibility:** Unknown/Limited
- No specific information available in current accessibility documentation
- Less actively maintained than LibreOffice
- Limited accessibility resources

**Not recommended** - insufficient accessibility track record and documentation.

---

## DETAILED EVALUATION SUMMARY TABLE

| Feature | LibreOffice | MS Office | OnlyOffice | Google Docs |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| NVDA Compatibility | Excellent | Excellent | Moderate (Beta) | Good (online) |
| Vietnamese Support | Full | Full | Good | Full |
| Beginner-Friendly | Very Good | Good | Moderate | Good |
| Keyboard Navigation | Excellent | Excellent | Good | Good |
| File Format Support | .odt/.docx | .docx | .docx/.odt | Google Formats |
| Offline Operation | Full | Full | Full (desktop) | Limited |
| Learning Resources | Good (AFB) | Excellent | Limited | Good |
| Cost | Free | Paid | Free | Free (web) |
| Add-ons for Access | Limited | Extensive | N/A | N/A |

---

## RECOMMENDATIONS FOR YOUR USE CASE

### Primary Recommendation: **LibreOffice 24.8 LTS Writer**

**Why this is best for complete beginners (children) learning to type:**

1. **Accessibility:** Rock-solid NVDA integration with no licensing concerns
2. **Cost:** Completely free - no budget constraints for a school or family
3. **Vietnamese Support:** Native language pack with community support
4. **Simplicity:** Fewer menu options than Microsoft Office means less overwhelming for children
5. **Educational Resources:** American Foundation for the Blind provides free training videos specifically for NVDA users
6. **Keyboard Focus:** Designed for keyboard-first interaction ideal for learning proper typing technique
7. **File Formats:** .odt files are accessibility-optimized for long-term usability

### File Format Recommendation: Use .odt (OpenDocument Text)
- Superior accessibility for screen readers
- Open standard with long-term accessibility guarantees
- Easily converted to .docx when needed
- Accessible through multiple applications

### Setup for Blind Children Learning to Type:

1. **Install NVDA** (free, latest version)
2. **Install LibreOffice Writer** 24.8 LTS (free)
3. **Enable Input Help in NVDA** (NVDA + H) - announces every keystroke and action
4. **Complete AFB "Learn NVDA" tutorials** before starting with documents
5. **Start with simple typing practice** before moving to formatting
6. **Use keyboard shortcuts exclusively** from the beginning

### NVDA Settings for Beginners:
- Enable "Input Help" for learning keyboard commands
- Disable "Speak typed characters/words" to avoid confusion (as Google Docs recommends)
- Configure speech rate for comfortable listening
- Use Vietnamese language pack in NVDA if available

---

## ADDITIONAL RESOURCES

- [LibreOffice Accessibility Documentation](https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Accessibility/Accessibility-dev)
- [Learn NVDA from American Foundation for the Blind](https://afb.org/blindness-and-low-vision/using-technology/assistive-technology-videos/learn-nvda)

- [OnlyOffice Screen Reader Guide](https://www.onlyoffice.com/blog/2023/10/screen-readers-in-onlyoffice)

---

## Comprehensive Screen Reader Comparison for Blind Children in Vietnam on Windows 11

Based on my research, here's a detailed evaluation of screen reader options focused on the critical context: **beginners who are children in Vietnam with no internet access**.

### SUMMARY & RECOMMENDATION

**BEST CHOICE: NVDA 2025.3.2** (Your current selection is optimal)

For beginners who are children in Vietnam without internet access, NVDA is decisively the best option. No other choice comes close when evaluating the specific requirements.

---

## DETAILED COMPARISON

### 1. NVDA 2025.3.2 - Free, Open-Source Screen Reader

#### Vietnamese Language Support
- **Interface**: NVDA is translated into 55 languages including Vietnamese
- **TTS (Text-to-Speech)**: Multiple options:
  - Windows OneCore voices (built into Windows 10/11) - supports Vietnamese
  - eSpeak NG synthesizer (included with NVDA) - provides fallback support
  - Third-party TTS options available: Tiflotecnia Voices for NVDA, Acapela voices
- **Status**: Full Vietnamese interface and TTS support confirmed

#### Braille Display Support
- **Orbit Reader 20 / APH displays**: Yes, fully supported
- **Vietnamese Braille**: Grade 1 Vietnamese braille translation table available (using LibLouis braille translator)
- **Configuration**: Simple setup - braille detected automatically, or configured in NVDA Settings > Braille
- **Status**: Excellent braille support with Vietnamese translation tables

#### Offline Operation
- **Critical Advantage**: NVDA requires NO internet connection after initial download
- **Portable Mode**: Can run from USB drive without installation (no admin rights needed)
- **Built-in TTS**: Windows OneCore voices are offline-capable after installation
- **Status**: Perfect for offline environments

#### Cost & Licensing
- **Price**: Free (US$0)
- **License**: Open-source under GPL
- **No subscriptions, no licensing restrictions**
- **Status**: Maximum accessibility for economically constrained regions

#### Ease of Use for Beginners/Children
- **Simplicity**: NVDA has a **simpler interface than JAWS**, less overwhelming for new users
- **Keyboard-focused**: Clear, learnable keyboard commands
- **Community Rating**: Ranked as second most popular screen reader (37.7% of WebAIM survey respondents use NVDA as primary)
- **Educational Resources**: Dedicated beginner training available
- **Status**: Specifically noted as easier for first-time users and children

#### Vietnamese Community Support & Documentation
- **Sao Mai Center for the Blind (SMCB)**: Established partner since NVDA's early development
- **Translated Materials**: Official training modules in Vietnamese:
  - NVDA Basics
  - Microsoft Office with NVDA (Word, Excel, etc.)
- **Impact in Schools**: Collaborates with Nguyen Dinh Chieu School teaching school-age children
- **Official Vietnamese Website**: www.nvda.vn
- **Training Results**: 400+ Vietnamese users trained through Sao Mai materials
- **Employment Success**: 32 people placed in employment using NVDA training
- **Status**: Strongest Vietnamese language community support

#### NVDA Add-ons for Education
- **NVDA Add-on Store**: Official repository at addonstore.nvaccess.org
- **MathCAT Add-on**: Includes Vietnamese braille support, helpful for mathematics learning
- **Educational Training Bundle**: "Basic Training for NVDA" eBook available (audio, braille, text formats)
- **No limitations**: Add-ons work fully offline
- **Status**: Growing ecosystem of educational add-ons

#### Windows 11 Compatibility
- Supports 64-bit Windows 11
- Fully compatible and regularly updated

#### STRENGTHS for Vietnam Context
✓ Free and open-source  
✓ Works completely offline  
✓ Full Vietnamese interface and TTS  
✓ Vietnamese Braille Grade 1 support  
✓ Orbit Reader 20 fully compatible  
✓ Simplest learning curve for beginners/children  
✓ Strongest Vietnamese community (Sao Mai Center)  
✓ Portable (no installation needed)  
✓ Proven in Vietnamese schools  
✓ No licensing restrictions  

---

### 2. JAWS - Commercial Screen Reader

#### Vietnamese Language Support
- **Interface**: Not available in Vietnamese
- **TTS**: Vietnamese language support is **NOT confirmed**
- **Supported interface languages**: English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Dutch, Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, Finnish (Vietnamese NOT listed)
- **Voice options**: 30+ languages claimed, but Vietnamese not explicitly documented
- **Status**: NO Vietnamese support

#### Braille Display Support
- **Orbit Reader 20**: Yes, supported
- **Vietnamese Braille**: No Vietnamese-specific support mentioned
- **Status**: Generic braille support only

#### Offline Operation
- **Requires**: Need to verify licensing requirements (may require online activation)
- **Status**: Less clear than NVDA

#### Cost & Licensing
- **Annual Home Edition**: $90/year (or $270 for 3 years, $450 for 5 years)
- **Perpetual Home License**: Higher upfront cost with Software Maintenance Agreement
- **Multi-computer**: Can activate on up to 3 computers for personal use
- **Status**: Expensive for families in Vietnam; ongoing subscription costs

#### Ease of Use for Beginners/Children
- **Complexity**: More features means steeper learning curve (less suitable for children)
- **Multiple customization options**: Can overwhelm beginners
- **Status**: NOT recommended for beginners

#### Vietnamese Community Support
- **None found**: No Vietnamese-specific training materials, communities, or support
- **Status**: Zero community support in Vietnam

#### JAWS Add-ons & Customization
- Limited to JAWS ecosystem; no equivalent to NVDA's open add-on community
- **Status**: Less extensible

#### CRITICAL DISADVANTAGES
✗ NO Vietnamese interface translation  
✗ NO Vietnamese TTS support documented  
✗ High annual cost ($90+/year)  
✗ More complex for beginners  
✗ No Vietnamese community support  
✗ Licensing restrictions  
✗ Less suitable for educational use in Vietnam  

---

### 3. Windows Narrator - Built-in Windows Screen Reader

#### Vietnamese Language Support
- **Interface**: Built-in, default language follows Windows OS setting
- **TTS**: Vietnamese not listed among initially supported voices
- **Natural Voices**: Vietnamese was NOT included in the September 2023 expansion (Chinese, Spanish, French, Portuguese, German, Japanese, Korean, English variants included - Vietnamese omitted)
- **Status**: Vietnamese support is UNCLEAR/LIMITED

#### Braille Display Support
- **Limited support**: Does not have extensive braille display compatibility
- **Orbit Reader 20**: Support unknown/likely limited
- **Status**: Inferior to NVDA and JAWS

#### Offline Operation
- **Voice models**: Must be downloaded and installed for offline use
- **Advanced features**: May require online services for image descriptions and webpage summaries
- **Status**: Partially offline-capable

#### Cost & Licensing
- **Price**: Free (included with Windows)
- **Status**: Cost advantage, but doesn't offset other limitations

#### Ease of Use for Beginners/Children
- **Simplicity**: Simplest of all options (built-in)
- **Limitations**: Very limited functionality compared to NVDA/JAWS
- **Status**: Easiest but least capable

#### Vietnamese Community Support
- **None**: No Vietnamese translation projects or community
- **Status**: No community support

#### CRITICAL LIMITATIONS
✗ Vietnamese TTS support unclear/not included in natural voices  
✗ Limited braille display support (Orbit Reader 20 compatibility unknown)  
✗ Very limited functionality overall  
✗ Inadequate for serious screen reader use  
✗ Not designed for advanced educational use  
✗ No Vietnamese community support  

---

### 4. Other Options (NVDA Forks, Alternatives)

#### NVDA-Based Forks
- **Status**: NVDA itself is open-source; forks exist but lack the community support of mainline NVDA
- **Recommendation**: Use official NVDA, not forks, to ensure community support in Vietnam

#### Orca Screen Reader
- **Platform**: Linux only (not Windows)
- **Status**: Not applicable for Windows 11

#### Thunder Screen Reader
- **Status**: Not widely recommended; NVDA is superior
- **Vietnamese support**: Not documented

#### Other alternatives
- All are either Linux-only, unmaintained, or inferior to NVDA for this use case

---

## DETAILED SCORING TABLE

| Criterion | NVDA | JAWS | Narrator | Winner |
|-----------|------|------|----------|---------|
| **Vietnamese Interface** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✗ (None) | ? (Unclear) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese TTS** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✗ (Not found) | ? (Unclear) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese Braille** | ✓✓ (Grade 1) | ✗ (None) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Orbit Reader 20** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✓ (Yes) | ? (Unknown) | NVDA |
| **Offline Operation** | ✓✓ (Perfect) | ? (Unclear) | ~ (Partial) | NVDA |
| **Cost** | ✓✓ (Free) | ✗ ($90+/yr) | ✓ (Free) | NVDA |
| **Beginner-Friendly** | ✓✓ (Yes) | ✗ (Complex) | ✓ (Simple) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese Community** | ✓✓ (Strong) | ✗ (None) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Educational Add-ons** | ✓✓ (Yes) | ~ (Limited) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Windows 11 Support** | ✓ (Yes) | ✓ (Yes) | ✓ (Yes) | Tie |

---

## FINAL RECOMMENDATION FOR VIETNAM CONTEXT

### NVDA 2025.3.2 is overwhelmingly the best choice because:

1. **Vietnamese-Specific**: The ONLY option with verified Vietnamese interface, TTS, and Braille support
2. **Completely Free**: No cost barriers for economically constrained families
3. **Offline Perfect**: Works completely offline after initial download - critical for Vietnam's internet infrastructure variability
4. **Proven in Vietnamese Schools**: Active use at Nguyen Dinh Chieu School teaching children
5. **Local Support**: Sao Mai Center for the Blind provides Vietnamese-language training and community
6. **Beginner-Optimal**: Simplest learning curve of all commercial/serious options
7. **Braille Ready**: Orbit Reader 20 support + Vietnamese Grade 1 braille included
8. **No Licensing Issues**: No restrictions on use or number of computers
9. **Portable**: Can run from USB without installation
10. **Accessible Training**: Vietnamese-translated beginner materials already exist

### Implementation Steps for Vietnam:
1. Download NVDA 2025.3.2 on a computer with internet access
2. Transfer via USB to offline computers
3. Install and configure Vietnamese interface
4. Configure Windows OneCore or eSpeak NG for Vietnamese TTS
5. If using Braille: Connect Orbit Reader 20 (auto-detected)
6. Reference Sao Mai Center materials at www.nvda.vn for Vietnamese training
7. Access NVDA Add-on Store for educational add-ons

Your current choice of NVDA 2025.3.2 is **definitively correct** for your use case.

---

✓ Full Vietnamese interface and TTS  
✓ Vietnamese Braille Grade 1 support  
✓ Orbit Reader 20 fully compatible  
✓ Simplest learning curve for beginners/children  
✓ Strongest Vietnamese community (Sao Mai Center)  
✓ Portable (no installation needed)  
✓ Proven in Vietnamese schools  
✓ No licensing restrictions  

---

### 2. JAWS - Commercial Screen Reader

#### Vietnamese Language Support
- **Interface**: Not available in Vietnamese
- **TTS**: Vietnamese language support is **NOT confirmed**
- **Supported interface languages**: English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Dutch, Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, Finnish (Vietnamese NOT listed)
- **Voice options**: 30+ languages claimed, but Vietnamese not explicitly documented
- **Status**: NO Vietnamese support

#### Braille Display Support
- **Orbit Reader 20**: Yes, supported
- **Vietnamese Braille**: No Vietnamese-specific support mentioned
- **Status**: Generic braille support only

#### Offline Operation
- **Requires**: Need to verify licensing requirements (may require online activation)
- **Status**: Less clear than NVDA

#### Cost & Licensing
- **Annual Home Edition**: $90/year (or $270 for 3 years, $450 for 5 years)
- **Perpetual Home License**: Higher upfront cost with Software Maintenance Agreement
- **Multi-computer**: Can activate on up to 3 computers for personal use
- **Status**: Expensive for families in Vietnam; ongoing subscription costs

#### Ease of Use for Beginners/Children
- **Complexity**: More features means steeper learning curve (less suitable for children)
- **Multiple customization options**: Can overwhelm beginners
- **Status**: NOT recommended for beginners

#### Vietnamese Community Support
- **None found**: No Vietnamese-specific training materials, communities, or support
- **Status**: Zero community support in Vietnam

#### JAWS Add-ons & Customization
- Limited to JAWS ecosystem; no equivalent to NVDA's open add-on community
- **Status**: Less extensible

#### CRITICAL DISADVANTAGES
✗ NO Vietnamese interface translation  
✗ NO Vietnamese TTS support documented  
✗ High annual cost ($90+/year)  
✗ More complex for beginners  
✗ No Vietnamese community support  
✗ Licensing restrictions  
✗ Less suitable for educational use in Vietnam  

---

### 3. Windows Narrator - Built-in Windows Screen Reader

#### Vietnamese Language Support
- **Interface**: Built-in, default language follows Windows OS setting
- **TTS**: Vietnamese not listed among initially supported voices
- **Natural Voices**: Vietnamese was NOT included in the September 2023 expansion (Chinese, Spanish, French, Portuguese, German, Japanese, Korean, English variants included - Vietnamese omitted)
- **Status**: Vietnamese support is UNCLEAR/LIMITED

#### Braille Display Support
- **Limited support**: Does not have extensive braille display compatibility
- **Orbit Reader 20**: Support unknown/likely limited
- **Status**: Inferior to NVDA and JAWS

#### Offline Operation
- **Voice models**: Must be downloaded and installed for offline use
- **Advanced features**: May require online services for image descriptions and webpage summaries
- **Status**: Partially offline-capable

#### Cost & Licensing
- **Price**: Free (included with Windows)
- **Status**: Cost advantage, but doesn't offset other limitations

#### Ease of Use for Beginners/Children
- **Simplicity**: Simplest of all options (built-in)
- **Limitations**: Very limited functionality compared to NVDA/JAWS
- **Status**: Easiest but least capable

#### Vietnamese Community Support
- **None**: No Vietnamese translation projects or community
- **Status**: No community support

#### CRITICAL LIMITATIONS
✗ Vietnamese TTS support unclear/not included in natural voices  
✗ Limited braille display support (Orbit Reader 20 compatibility unknown)  
✗ Very limited functionality overall  
✗ Inadequate for serious screen reader use  
✗ Not designed for advanced educational use  
✗ No Vietnamese community support  

---

### 4. Other Options (NVDA Forks, Alternatives)

#### NVDA-Based Forks
- **Status**: NVDA itself is open-source; forks exist but lack the community support of mainline NVDA
- **Recommendation**: Use official NVDA, not forks, to ensure community support in Vietnam

#### Orca Screen Reader
- **Platform**: Linux only (not Windows)
- **Status**: Not applicable for Windows 11

#### Thunder Screen Reader
- **Status**: Not widely recommended; NVDA is superior
- **Vietnamese support**: Not documented

#### Other alternatives
- All are either Linux-only, unmaintained, or inferior to NVDA for this use case

---

## DETAILED SCORING TABLE

| Criterion | NVDA | JAWS | Narrator | Winner |
|-----------|------|------|----------|---------|
| **Vietnamese Interface** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✗ (None) | ? (Unclear) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese TTS** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✗ (Not found) | ? (Unclear) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese Braille** | ✓✓ (Grade 1) | ✗ (None) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Orbit Reader 20** | ✓✓ (Full) | ✓ (Yes) | ? (Unknown) | NVDA |
| **Offline Operation** | ✓✓ (Perfect) | ? (Unclear) | ~ (Partial) | NVDA |
| **Cost** | ✓✓ (Free) | ✗ ($90+/yr) | ✓ (Free) | NVDA |
| **Beginner-Friendly** | ✓✓ (Yes) | ✗ (Complex) | ✓ (Simple) | NVDA |
| **Vietnamese Community** | ✓✓ (Strong) | ✗ (None) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Educational Add-ons** | ✓✓ (Yes) | ~ (Limited) | ✗ (None) | NVDA |
| **Windows 11 Support** | ✓ (Yes) | ✓ (Yes) | ✓ (Yes) | Tie |

---

## FINAL RECOMMENDATION FOR VIETNAM CONTEXT

### NVDA 2025.3.2 is overwhelmingly the best choice because:

1. **Vietnamese-Specific**: The ONLY option with verified Vietnamese interface, TTS, and Braille support
2. **Completely Free**: No cost barriers for economically constrained families
3. **Offline Perfect**: Works completely offline after initial download - critical for Vietnam's internet infrastructure variability
4. **Proven in Vietnamese Schools**: Active use at Nguyen Dinh Chieu School teaching children
5. **Local Support**: Sao Mai Center for the Blind provides Vietnamese-language training and community
6. **Beginner-Optimal**: Simplest learning curve of all commercial/serious options
7. **Braille Ready**: Orbit Reader 20 support + Vietnamese Grade 1 braille included
8. **No Licensing Issues**: No restrictions on use or number of computers
9. **Portable**: Can run from USB without installation
10. **Accessible Training**: Vietnamese-translated beginner materials already exist

### Implementation Steps for Vietnam:
1. Download NVDA 2025.3.2 on a computer with internet access
2. Transfer via USB to offline computers
3. Install and configure Vietnamese interface
4. Configure Windows OneCore or eSpeak NG for Vietnamese TTS
5. If using Braille: Connect Orbit Reader 20 (auto-detected)
6. Reference Sao Mai Center materials at www.nvda.vn for Vietnamese training
7. Access NVDA Add-on Store for educational add-ons

Your current choice of NVDA 2025.3.2 is **definitively correct** for your use case.

---

# Vietnamese Text-to-Speech in Windows 11

Yes, Windows 11 includes Vietnamese text-to-speech support. According to the official documentation, the available voice is:

**Male voice:** "An"

There is no female Vietnamese voice currently available. The table lists Vietnamese as having only a single male TTS voice option, with "Not applicable" indicated for the female voice category.

data.prompt:
Research Vietnamese text-to-speech (TTS) options for NVDA screen reader on Windows 11.

Current choice: Sao Mai VNVoice v1.0 (SAPI5)

Investigate and compare:
1. **Sao Mai VNVoice** - What are the voices? Quality? Is it still maintained?
2. **eSpeak-NG** - Does it have Vietnamese? Quality?
3. **Microsoft Vietnamese voices** - Does Windows 11 include Vietnamese TTS?
4. **Other Vietnamese TTS options** - Are there other free Vietnamese SAPI5 or NVDA-compatible voices?

For each, analyze:
- Voice quality and naturalness
- Child-friendliness (not robotic, pleasant to listen to for hours)
- Compatibility with NVDA
- Offline operation
- Cost/licensing
- Pronunciation accuracy for Vietnamese tones

Also research: What is Sao Mai Center? Are they reliable? What other software do they provide?

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have comprehensive information. Let me compile my findings into a detailed research report.

## Vietnamese TTS Research Report for NVDA on Windows 11

Based on my research, here's a comprehensive comparison of Vietnamese text-to-speech options for NVDA on Windows 11:

---

### **1. Sao Mai VNVoice v1.0 (Your Current Choice)**

**Organization Background:**
[Sao Mai Center for the Blind (SMCB)][1] is a non-profit organization established in 2001 in Vietnam, dedicated to empowering blind people through assistive technology. They are reliable and maintain an active presence with software development, documentation, and community engagement. They've been a key collaborator with NVDA developers since its early stages.

**Voices Available:**
- **Minh Du** (Female)
- **Mai Dung** (Female)
- English voice (built-in)

**Quality & Naturalness:**
- First SAPI5 Vietnamese TTS engine for Windows (pioneering technology since ~2002)
- Still widely used by blind computer users in Vietnam
- **Limitations:** Voice quality reviews are limited; appears to use concatenative synthesis rather than neural-based synthesis, which may result in less natural prosody compared to newer AI-based systems
- No specific user reviews available comparing voice naturalness or child-friendliness

**NVDA Compatibility:**
- Excellent - SAPI5 compliant and well-integrated with NVDA
- Sao Mai has developed NVDA add-ons and localized NVDA into Vietnamese

**Technical Specs:**
- SAPI5 compliant - works on all Windows versions with SAPI5 support
- Supports Unicode, VNI, and ABC encodings
- File size: 250MB
- Offline operation: Yes, fully offline

**Cost/Licensing:**
- Free

**Tone/Pronunciation Accuracy:**
- Specifically designed for Vietnamese with tone support
- Limited information on tone accuracy vs. alternatives

**Child-Friendliness:**
- No specific information available, but limited feedback suggests quality may be adequate but not premium

**Assessment:** Solid, proven choice with excellent NVDA integration and community trust, but shows age in voice synthesis technology.

---

### **2. Windows 11 Native Microsoft Voices**

**Availability:**
[Windows 11 includes Vietnamese speech-to-text support][2], but TTS is minimal:
- **Single male voice available:** "An"
- No female voice option
- Requires installing Vietnamese language pack

**Voice Quality:**
- Limited information on quality
- As a native Windows voice, likely uses neural synthesis (newer than Sao Mai VNVoice)
- Potential for better naturalness than older concatenative synthesis

**NVDA Compatibility:**
- Fully compatible - SAPI5 compliant
- May not be as well-integrated as Sao Mai VNVoice with Vietnamese-specific features

**Offline Operation:**
- Yes, after language pack installation

**Cost/Licensing:**
- Free (part of Windows 11)

**Limitations:**
- Single male voice only
- May not be optimized for Vietnamese tones and prosody as well as purpose-built Vietnamese TTS
- Limited customization compared to specialized engines

**Assessment:** Convenient built-in option but limited voice choices and uncertain quality optimization for Vietnamese.

---

### **3. NHMTTS (NHM Text-to-Speech) - Free SAPI5 Alternative**

**Voices Available:**
- NHMTTS Voice (Male)
- NHMTTS Voice (Female)

**Quality & Naturalness:**
- Uses **artificial neural network** synthesis
- Advertised as "natural voices"
- More modern approach than Sao Mai VNVoice
- No detailed user reviews or comparative quality assessments available

**NVDA Compatibility:**
- Fully compatible - SAPI5 compliant
- Works with Thunder and NVDA screen readers

**Technical Specs:**
- SAPI5 compliant
- Offline operation: Yes
- [Available for free download][3]

**Cost/Licensing:**
- Free

**Tone/Pronunciation Accuracy:**
- Modern neural approach should handle tones better than older synthesis
- Limited specific feedback on Vietnamese tone accuracy

**Child-Friendliness:**
- Unknown - no user feedback available

**Assessment:** Promising neural-based alternative with both male and female voices, but lacks user reviews or quality verification.

---

### **4. eSpeak-NG - Open Source Alternative**

**Vietnamese Support:**
- [Technically supports Vietnamese][4] with phoneme definitions and tone support

**Voice Quality:**
- **POOR for Vietnamese** - [GitHub issue #951 reports "Vietnamese has not been pronounced properly"][5]
- Mispronounced and inconsistent with how native speakers pronounce Vietnamese
- Described by users as unacceptable compared to Google TTS and Vocalizer TTS
- Acceptable only when compared to basic Eloquence TTS
- **Robotic quality** - lacks expressiveness and natural prosody

**NVDA Compatibility:**
- Compatible but not optimal

**Technical Specs:**
- Open source
- Lightweight resource usage
- Offline operation: Yes

**Tone/Pronunciation Accuracy:**
- **Inadequate** - Tones are "just a guess without proper feedback from native speakers"
- Not recommended for Vietnamese

**Child-Friendliness:**
- Robotic voice quality makes it unsuitable for extended listening by children

**Assessment:** Not recommended due to poor Vietnamese pronunciation and robotic voice quality.

---

### **5. Other Vietnamese TTS Options (Reference)**

Several newer options exist but are **NOT SAPI5 compliant** and would **NOT work directly with NVDA** without additional adapters:

- **[VieNeu-TTS][6]** - Open source, neural-based, 24kHz quality, instant voice cloning, on-device, real-time CPU inference
- **[VietTTS][7]** - Open source toolkit, natural voice synthesis, voice cloning support
- **[ElevenLabs Vietnamese][8]** - Commercial, high-quality neural voices, captures tonal richness (cloud-based, requires internet)
- **Natural Voice SAPI Adapter** - Can bridge Azure neural voices to SAPI5 applications, but requires Azure subscription

These are not practical for NVDA offline operation on Windows without significant technical setup.

---

### **Comparison Summary Table**

| Feature | Sao Mai VNVoice | Windows 11 "An" | NHMTTS | eSpeak-NG |
|---------|---|---|---|---|
| **Voices** | 2 female | 1 male | 1 male, 1 female | 1 generic |
| **Voice Quality** | Adequate/proven | Unknown | Promising (neural) | Poor/robotic |
| **Child-Friendly** | Unknown | Unknown | Unknown | No |
| **Tone Accuracy** | Good | Unknown | Modern approach | Poor |
| **NVDA Compatible** | Excellent | Good | Good | Compatible |
| **Offline** | Yes | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| **Cost** | Free | Free | Free | Free |
| **Maintenance** | Active in community | Microsoft-backed | Unknown | Active (open source) |
| **File Size** | 250MB | Varies | Unknown | Small |

---

### **Recommendations**

**For your current use case (child-friendly NVDA on Windows 11):**

1. **Best Option: Stick with Sao Mai VNVoice v1.0**
   - Proven track record in Vietnam's blind community
   - Excellent NVDA integration with dedicated support
   - Both male and female voices (if you prefer variety)
   - Reliable organization backing
   - Well-understood pronunciation accuracy
   - The main downside is potentially older synthesis technology

2. **Try NHMTTS as an Alternative**
   - Modern neural synthesis should provide better naturalness
   - Both male and female voices
   - Free and SAPI5 compliant
   - **Risk:** Minimal user feedback and quality verification
   - Could test alongside Sao Mai for comparison

3. **Avoid eSpeak-NG for Vietnamese**
   - Confirmed poor pronunciation and robotic quality
   - Not suitable for extended listening

4. **Windows 11 "An" Voice**
   - Only as fallback due to limited options (single male voice)
   - May be worth testing if you're curious about Microsoft's neural synthesis

---

### **Further Testing Recommendations**

Since voice quality is subjective and child-comfort is important, I recommend:

1. **Download and test NHMTTS** for 1-2 weeks alongside Sao Mai to compare naturalness and tone accuracy
2. **Record sample sentences** with both voices and have the child provide feedback on which sounds more pleasant
3. **Check tone-critical words** - test phrases with different tones to verify accuracy
4. **Assess fatigue** - which voice causes less listening fatigue over extended sessions

---

### **Sao Mai Center Software Ecosystem**

[Sao Mai Center provides several free software solutions][9]:
- **Sao Mai VNVoice** - Vietnamese TTS (your current tool)
- **Sao Mai Braille (SMB)** - Free rich-text editor and Braille translator
- **DoudouLinux Vietnamese** - Educational software for children (40+ language translations)
- **Go tiếng Việt** - Vietnamese language learning program

This demonstrates they're a reliable, established organization with diverse accessibility software focus.

---

### **Sources:**

- [Sao Mai VNVoice | Sao Mai Center for the Blind (SMCB)][1]
- [Appendix A: Supported languages and voices - Microsoft Support][2]
- [NHMTTS SAPI5 3.0 Free Download][3]
- [eSpeak-NG GitHub Languages Documentation][4]
- [eSpeak Vietnamese Pronunciation Issue #951][5]
- [GitHub - pnnbao97/VieNeu-TTS][6]
- [GitHub - NTT123/vietTTS][7]
- [Free Vietnamese Text to Speech & Vietnamese AI Voices - ElevenLabs][8]
- [Software | Sao Mai Center for the Blind (SMCB)][9]
- [NVDA Addon store][10]
- [NVDA Support for Vietnamese Language][11]

[1]: https://saomaicenter.org/en/smsoft/vnvoice
[2]: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/appendix-a-supported-languages-and-voices-4486e345-7730-53da-fcfe-55cc64300f01
[3]: https://nhmtts-sapi5.soft112.com
[4]: https://github.com/espeak-ng/espeak-ng/blob/master/docs/languages.md
[5]: https://github.com/espeak-ng/espeak-ng/issues/951
[6]: https://github.com/pnnbao97/VieNeu-TTS
[7]: https://github.com/NTT123/vietTTS
[8]: https://elevenlabs.io/text-to-speech/vietnamese
[9]: https://saomaicenter.org/en/smsoft
[10]: https://nvda.store/
[11]: https://nvaccess.org/download/

- **Sao Mai VNVoice** - Vietnamese TTS (your current tool)
- **Sao Mai Braille (SMB)** - Free rich-text editor and Braille translator
- **DoudouLinux Vietnamese** - Educational software for children (40+ language translations)
- **Go tiếng Việt** - Vietnamese language learning program

This demonstrates they're a reliable, established organization with diverse accessibility software focus.

---

## NVDA and Chrome Support

The recommended browser for NVDA is Chrome. More broadly, NVDA has robust support for browsing the web using Mozilla Firefox and Google Chrome.

NVDA works well with browsers like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, and other accessibility-compliant software. Additionally, NVDA works with web browsers such as Mozilla Firefox, Google Chrome, Internet Explorer, and Microsoft Edge.

## Current Accessibility Testing

For those testing web accessibility with NVDA and Chrome in 2026, NVDA's output may change depending on your web browser, so testing specifically with Chrome is important for accurate results.

I've completed the web search for your query about NVDA, Microsoft Edge accessibility, browse mode, and Windows 11. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## NVDA Compatibility with Microsoft Edge

Microsoft has tested accessibility instructions with NVDA, JAWS, and Narrator, and NVDA works well with Edge, with NVDA + Edge being one of the best tested combinations.

## Browse Mode Support

All NVDA browse mode features users have come to expect in other browsers are now available in Edge, such as finding text, table navigation, automatic language switching, and quick navigation by heading, table, and button.

## Recent Improvements

When using Microsoft Edge with UI Automation, NVDA is able to activate more controls in browse mode. Additionally, NVDA will no longer fail to read a newly loaded page in Microsoft Edge when using UI Automation.

## Windows 11 and NVDA

NVDA supports all 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows 8.1, Windows 10, Windows 11, and all Server Operating Systems starting from Windows Server 2012 R2.

The search results show that NVDA has made significant progress in supporting Microsoft Edge, including proper browse mode functionality, particularly with recent updates to the screen reader.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding NVDA, Firefox ESR, accessibility, and Windows 11 in 2026:

## Firefox ESR Support Timeline

Firefox ESR 115 will continue to receive security updates on Windows 7, 8, and 8.1 until March 2026. Mozilla will re-evaluate the situation in February 2026, to decide whether to end support for Firefox 115 ESR.

## NVDA and Firefox Compatibility

Firefox is the most used browser by NVDA users, and the latest ESR (Extended Support Release) version of Firefox will provide the best compatibility with NVDA.

## NVDA on Windows 11

NVDA supports all 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows 8.1, Windows 10, Windows 11, and all Server Operating Systems starting from Windows Server 2012 R2, including both AMD64 and ARM64 variants of Windows.

## Accessibility Improvements

The native HTML date picker for date and datetime inputs can now be used with a keyboard alone, improving its accessibility for screen reader users, and users with limited mobility can now use common keyboard shortcuts to navigate the calendar. Additionally, Windows' "Make text bigger" accessibility setting now affects all the UI and content pages in Firefox.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about VLC Media Player accessibility with NVDA for blind users:

## Accessibility Overview

VLC Media Player works well with popular screen readers, making it accessible for visually impaired users.

## NVDA Add-ons Available

There are several NVDA add-ons designed to enhance accessibility for VLC Media Player:

**Main Features:**
The addon provides some accessibility features for VLC Media Player, allows navigating through the playback controls using Tab and Shift+Tab, and to activate a selected control press enter.

**Advanced Enhancements:**
One addon adds various commands to enhance accessibility including scripts to announce media duration (played and remaining), current speed, and automatic announcements of state changes such as pause, volume mute, speed, repeat or random playback states.

**Additional Features:**
The addon reads status bar information and announces elapsed time when moving back and forward using VLC keystrokes.

## Compatibility

The addon is optimized for versions of VLC 3.0 and higher; it will not work correctly with earlier versions.

Another addon requires minimum NVDA version 2024.1 and is compatible with VLC 3.0.

These add-ons make VLC significantly more accessible for blind and visually impaired users by providing detailed audio feedback and improved keyboard navigation.

Links: [{"title":"Windows 11 24H2 Archive Support: ZIP, 7z, TAR & Limitations","url":"https://www.tweaknow.com/RegTweakNativeArchive.php"},{"title":"Windows 11 Compression Guide: Built‑in ZIP vs 7‑Zip and Robocopy for Large Transfers | Windows Forum","url":"https://windowsforum.com/threads/windows-11-compression-guide-built-in-zip-vs-7-zip-and-robocopy-for-large-transfers.392009/"},{"title":"Mastering File Compression on Windows 10 & 11: Ultimate Guide to ZIP, RAR, 7Z & More | Windows Forum","url":"https://windowsforum.com/threads/mastering-file-compression-on-windows-10-11-ultimate-guide-to-zip-rar-7z-more.367711/"},{"title":"Which one is better WinRAR or the built-in zip feature? | Windows 11 Forum","url":"https://www.elevenforum.com/t/which-one-is-better-winrar-or-the-built-in-zip-feature.7873/"},{"title":"Windows 11 gets native RAR support, here is how it compares to WinRAR and other apps - Neowin","url":"https://www.neowin.net/news/windows-11-gets-native-rar-support-here-is-how-it-compares-to-winrar-and-other-apps/"},{"title":"This is the perfect hybrid of 7zip and WinRAR I've been waiting for","url":"https://www.xda-developers.com/perfect-hybrid-of-7zip-and-winrar/"},{"title":"SQUISH IT! or Windows 11 Natively Supporting 7-Zip Led Me to Muse About Drive Space | by Douglas Wayne Ricketts | Medium","url":"https://douglasricketts.medium.com/squish-it-or-windows-11-natively-supporting-7-zip-led-me-to-muse-about-drive-space-18acac6c43c2"},{"title":"Best 7-Zip Alternatives & Competitors","url":"https://sourceforge.net/software/product/7-Zip/alternatives"},{"title":"Top 7-Zip Alternatives in 2025","url":"https://slashdot.org/software/p/7-Zip/alternatives"},{"title":"10 Best WinRAR Alternatives & Competitors","url":"https://tutorialtactic.com/blog/best-winrar-alternatives/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about Windows 11's built-in compression support and alternatives:

## Windows 11 Built-in Support

Windows 11 24H2 now allows users to create ZIP, 7z, or TAR files directly from File Explorer and extract supported archive formats—including ZIP, RAR, 7z, and TAR—without installing additional tools. However, Windows 11 can extract RAR files but cannot create them, and only ZIP, 7z, and TAR can be created; no RAR, ISO, or other less common formats.

## Key Limitations

Windows' native tools lack password protection or encryption, and only basic extraction is guaranteed for RAR and 7Z, and attempting to extract password-protected RAR5 files consistently fails unless using WinRAR.

## Recommended Alternatives to 7-Zip

**7-Zip and PeaZip**: 7-Zip is an open-source file archiver with a high compression ratio, wide format support, and strong AES-256 encryption. PeaZip is an open-source utility supporting 200+ archive formats, with encryption, secure file deletion, and split archive features.

**NanaZip**: NanaZip blends efficiency with a slick UI and integrates well with Windows File Explorer, supporting formats including 7z, ZIP, TAR, GZ, BZ2, and XZ. Like 7-Zip, it's completely open-source and works well with both Windows 10 and 11.

**Bandizip**: Bandizip is a robust archiving tool with incredibly fast processing speeds, compatible with Windows 7-11, and allows extraction from over 30 different formats, such as RAR, RAR5, 7Z, and ZIP.

**WinRAR**: WinRAR remains the only software capable of creating RAR archives, including the modern RAR5 format and password-protected options.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## NVDA Compatibility with Windows 11

NVDA supports all 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows 11, and version 2025.3 of NVDA is now available for download.

## NVDA's General Accessibility Features

NVDA (Non-Visual Desktop Access) allows blind and vision impaired people to access and interact with the Windows operating system and many third party applications. NVDA includes support for popular applications including web browsers such as Mozilla Firefox and Google Chrome, email clients, internet chat software, music players, and office programs such as Microsoft Word and Excel.

## Regarding Calculator Apps Specifically

While the search results provide extensive information about NVDA's general compatibility and features, they don't contain specific information about accessible calculator applications for Windows 11 with NVDA support. I've found comprehensive information about NVDA add-ons. Here's what the search revealed:

## About NVDA Add-ons

The NVDA Add-ons Directory contains over 505 add-ons available, and add-ons are programs which provide new or changed functionality for NVDA, developed by the NVDA community or external companies.

## Helpful Add-ons for Educational Use

Based on the available add-ons, several can be beneficial for educational purposes:

- An add-on that helps new computer users understand how to interact with controls by pressing NVDA+H to get help messages on using the focused control

- An AI-powered image description tool that allows users to press NVDA+Control+I to get descriptions of objects or files

- MathCAT integration for full reading of mathematical expressions is planned as a future enhancement

## Educational Outreach Initiatives

NV Access is launching "Programming 101," a curated learning portal to help blind/visually impaired students transition from NVDA users to developers as part of their 2026 roadmap.

Additionally, NVDA has helped people get an education, and its portable nature makes it easy to use on school and university computers.

For the most current and complete list of available add-ons, you can visit the official NVDA Add-on Store at addonstore.nvaccess.org or nvda-addons.org.
